title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: It was years since I had been to Scotland, indeed I had only once crossed the border and that when I was a babe; consequently I was delighted to receive an invitation to spend a few weeks in the land of my birth. I went to Edinburgh first--I was born in Drumsheugh Gardens--and thence to Glamis.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: 388 OLD DIARIES [1900 the second son, " Willie," a tall youth, but short compared to his colossally tall sisters. I went into Edinburgh one day to see my old friend Charles Chambers ; he is now married, and lives in a hand some house in Drumsheugh Gardens ; his country house is at Dunkeld. How these northern publishers do flourish ! On returning from Edinburgh, I found at Newbyth fresh guests ; these were Mr and Mrs Berkeley, and her sister, Miss Wilmont.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: He owed to his dear friend Peters a great part of what he drank, and it was Peters, too, who listened to his muttering, his vague threats, his half-confidences about someone whose name he always held back, but whom he would have down in the mud, or his name was not Rivers. This had lasted far on into the previous night, after his retreat from Drumsheugh Gardens. It began again with little variation the next morning, only he got confused in his maundering before he collapsed, and substituted " Buncombe " for " Rivers," at which the attentive Peters laughed amusedly, but said nothing.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: He would walk it off, he thought, and hurried away against the wind. But he only went, scarcely conscious, as far as Drumsheugh Gardens, where he passed and repassed No. 45, attracted, time after time, by the steady light in Lord Inch s study, until at last he remembered that there would be danger in drawing the attention of the constable on the beat, and returned, cursing, to his room.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: and Margaret started for Drumsheugh Gardens, whither Henry Gordon accompanied her; ever and anon lost in either wonder or boundless admiration, and little dreaming that these same scenes would one day meet his gaze under such widely different impressions.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: Besides turning the key, he dragged a table across against the door, and against the table he tilted a chair, so that a push would make it go over. Then he undressed, and, after turning down the light, looked out quietly to see whether anyone haunted the House of Resi dence, as he had haunted Drumsheugh Gardens. But the white streets were quiet and empty.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: " Perhaps you are right. Will you go to Drumsheugh Gardens then if I arrange an hour ? I could harmlessly

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Thae Gordons hae been the blessin' tae Mistress Blain, I can teU ye, for afore she got them, she was whiles hard enough pressed. I min' o' Reuben lendin' her five shiUings tae tide her ower tiU Marget's money came in frae Drumsheugh Gardens; an' I min' fine o' twa Sabbaths when she cudna gang tae the kirk because her boots were dune. I wonner if Marget helps her ony the noo ? Ye never heard 'Leesbeth say?

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Lieutenant Prescott divided his time between Drumsheugh Gardens and Leith Walk; like aU other interested parties, taking it for granted that his Irish friend and the Heiress were " booked through," as he termed it. The scales of misconception, however, dropped from his eyes a few evenings after Myrtle's return.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: Ix a house not far from No. 45 Drumsheugh Gardens, that confirmed bachelor and well-known physician, Dr. Maitland, was sitting down to his dinner the same evening, when his man handed him a note from Xo. 45.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: The quiet repose of Drumsheugh Gardens, or the sight of these preparations for habitation, interested him so much that the following morning, at about half-past ten, Mr. Peters chose to smoke a cigar in that direction again. He had scarcely turned in at the eastern end, when he saw a

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: For another thing, the young fellow had been very much sobered by a chat with Maitland, who, meeting him in Drumsheugh Gardens one day, had invited him in, and talked gravely of Lord Inch s condition.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: With him came his son, Archibald, a young fellow of nineteen or twenty a youngster who in face took after his dead mother, who had been a silly, pretty woman of fashion, with a full purse when the young advocate married her. So the brown paper came down from the windows of 45 Drumsheugh Gardens, and Morris, Lord Inch s footman, standing on the doorsteps after a holiday in the country, looked around him to see if there were any changes, and noted with satisfaction, being a man of taste, that No. 46 had engaged a pretty housemaid. He also saw a foreign gentleman stroll quietly past, with the air of a stranger who was admiring Drums heugh Gardens as they deserved to be admired.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Poor Mrs. Blain was sorely perplexed. She knew the young men would both be at Drumsheugh Gardens, but how was she to get the hasty message conveyed to them ? Fancying old Mr. M'Chestney had had a " stroke " (as he was very feeble when Henry last left home), she determined to put on her bonnet and gloves, and hurry over with the missive herself.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: " Miss Blain is at Drumsheugh Gardens in charge of the Buchanan chUdren during the absence of their mother in London ; but if it's anything urgent, would I do instead, Gardner ?"

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Mrs. Blain's ill-humour showed no signs of dissipating until toward noon, when the lowering clouds drifted away. Mary started for Drumsheugh Gardens to carry home some white-work she had been embroidering for Edith Buchanan. Henry was to lunch with his uncle, so he need not be expected until evening; aud William Maxwell took the train for Glasgow, to visit his parents, and also to deliver a small parcel which Tom Hinde had entrusted to his charge for a sister in the Trongate shop.

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: " You mean to say that you must reside at Drumsheugh Gardens for two whole weeks ?" inquired Myrtle with eager interest.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: LORD INCH left the Parliament House for the last time that night, carried thence to Drumsheugh Gardens in a hearse that bore a snowy pall before it reached his door. For the snow that had threatened in the morning had fallen all through the afternoon, and still drifted down, making all the streets white and silent for his last home-coming.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: As for their going together, that was a great deal better than for her to go alone. They would cross up by the house in Drumsheugh Gardens, which he had not yet left, and she should wait at a quiet corner where she wouldn t be noticed, while he fetched his bicycle. Melia scolded and implored, all to no purpose.

title: Mr. Peters :
author: Stephens, Riccardo.
snippet: " I don t know that he will, but he does come in at tinies. It s Mr. Inch, from Drumsheugh Gardens, Miss Xelly, and he d be frightened to see you here, an me away. Will you please tell him, from me, that I m all right, only I ve got a cold, and I ll be out again to-morrow ?"

title: Bloom of Faded Years. [A novel.]
author: Downe, Walmer.
snippet: Drumsheugh Gardens. Thursday.
